—The answer to that question is—
—No.

PARA.TAB: If you want to debate us on tax, we will go to the opposition's record on taxation when it was in government. The first and plainest thing that anyone can see is that you are a high taxing party; we are not. We are a low taxing party. —What, after 12 years?

—That is right; it is very slow to change. Those dangerous industrial pyromaniacs over there could put it all in jeopardy, just as the Western Australians are. PARA.TAB: We spent a lot of money trying to change Australia's image, trying to lift the perception in the public eye of Australia as a reliable trading partner for commodities and, in particular, for manufactures and services. All the work that this government has done, not by itself but with the trade union movement, with business and with most of the state governments has helped to turn this image around. It has meant that eventually the reality of the low level of industrial disputes in Australia is starting to impinge on the consciousness of business internationally. It will be a terrible tragedy if the ideological blinkers of the Western Australian government and its commitment to seek to destroy the trade unions and the wage standards of Australian workers put all this at risk.

While I have strong views about the industrial dispute, I am not talking about its merits. I am talking about the provocative actions of the Western Australian government and the need for it to put aside its ideological blinkers, think about the national interest and not destroy the hard work that the government, other state governments, businesses and trade unions have put in place to bring about this remarkable transformation in our industrial relations, which has been of great assistance to our international image and our marketing performance abroad. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: what is the government's response to the two extraordinary sets of allegations made about the minister's department by the Liberal member for Deakin, Mr Aldred, in the House of Representatives yesterday, first, that the secretary to his department, Mr Michael Costello, has been involved, together with Mr Mark Leibler and Israeli intelligence agents, in the receipt of a large sum of money from the government of Surinam for services rendered to international drug trafficking; secondly, that a named diplomat and three others identified by position are involved in a group of some 20 senior officers engaged in paedophile activities in Australia and overseas, that this is known and tolerated by DFAT management, and that the department has actively obstructed police attempting to investigate this activity? Is there any substance to any of these allegations, and what is the government doing to investigate them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say at the outset that in my 17 years in this parliament I have never seen worse abuses of parliamentary privilege than those perpetrated by the member for Deakin yesterday. I also say at the outset that I do warmly welcome the statements that were made this morning by Mr Downer in respect of the allegations against the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and its officers and by Mr Howard in relation to the allegation specifically against Mr Leibler, in both cases regretting Mr Aldred's behaviour and dissociating themselves and the party from that. I think that was an appropriate response and I am grateful for it.

PARA.TAB: So far as Mr Costello is concerned, let me state for the parliamentary record what I have already said publicly. I accept absolutely Mr Costello's statement to me that there is not a shred of truth to these allegations. Michael Costello is one of Australia's finest public servants, with an outstanding public reputation. I have the utmost confidence in him and no intention whatever of standing him down, as I was urged to do by Mr Aldred.

Like Mr Costello and Mr Leibler, who has also been grossly and irresponsibly defamed, I welcome a full and rigorous examination of these matters by the Australian Federal Police working with their international colleagues. I have no doubt that this inquiry will establish that the allegations are utterly without foundation and will as well also help to expose something of the motivations of those responsible for producing this material in the first place and putting it on the public record.

So far as the alleged paedophile activities are concerned, let me confirm some of the basic points that were put on the record by Mr Bilney in the other place last night. First, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not, does not and will not ever condone paedophile activities by any of its officers. Secondly, when some allegations were drawn to attention in the past, in 1988 and 1993, they were the subject of full investigation by the Australian Federal Police and were found not to be substantiated. When allegations were made again in April this year, the AFP responded to our request for advice and for investigative action as appropriate, but there was no new information warranting an investigation. If new allegations are made with sufficient precision by Mr Aldred or anyone else to enable them to be investigated, then of course we would want that to happen. If Mr Aldred has any specific evidence, he should hand it over immediately to the AFP.

I should also make it clear that my department has not let matters rest there. It may possibly be that, irrespective of whether criminal activity is involved, conduct may have occurred which should properly be subject to Public Service disciplinary proceedings. The department has, accordingly, some weeks ago, set in train an internal investigation, which is still under way, to consider those questions. Mr Costello has himself put out a much more detailed statement on all of this today, and I seek leave to incorporate the text of that in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE—NEWS RELEASE

PARA.EMPHASIS: PRESS STATEMENT BY MR MICHAEL COSTELLO, SECRETARY

ANSWER.PARA: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE
ALLEGATIONS BY MR ALDRED MP AGAINST THE DEPARTMENT OF
FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE ON PAEDOPHILE ACTIVITY

In a statement to the Parliament yesterday, Mr Aldred MP, raised a number of allegations of alleged paedophile activity in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. One specific allegation he makes is that I, as Secretary of the Department, did not veto the promotion of an officer to a senior position in the Department even though I was allegedly aware of that of officer's paedophile proclivities. That allegation by Mr Aldred is a foul, loathsome, cowardly lie.

Mr Aldred also alleged in Parliament yesterday that the senior management of DFAT, not only tolerates known paedophiles in the Department but actively promotes them. That is also a foul, baseless lie.

Mr Aldred goes on to say that there are approximately 20 senior executive service officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who engage in paedophile activities within Australia and overseas. He refers specifically to Mr John Holloway by name and identifies another serving DFAT officer by reference to his current position. Similar allegations were reported in the Australian media sourced to a Philippines anti-paedophile activist some months ago. The Department immediately wrote to the Attorney-General's Department and to the Federal Police to ask them to investigate the matter of these allegations involving these two officers.

The Department has received advice from both the Federal Police and from the Attorney-General's Department that following their enquiries there is no evidence to support any allegations of involvement of either of these officers in paedophile activities. To be absolutely sure, however, I instructed our Embassy in Manila to pursue with the source of the Philippines allegations whether there was any concrete evidence that would support action against those officers under the Public Service Act, as distinct from the Crimes Act.

Our Embassy in Manila has now reported to me that Embassy officers there have had discussions (in the company of officers of the Child Welfare Department) with Dr Zaide the source of the earlier allegations. Dr Zaide, after a long discussion, acknowledged that she was unable to provide any specific evidence or substantiation of allegations that Australian diplomats had been involved in paedophile activities.

Mr Aldred also refers to a former DFAT officer currently working in Hanoi. That officer has not been a member of this Department for a decade. Any questions, therefore, relating to him should be addressed elsewhere.

Mr Aldred also specifies a former Australian Ambassador stationed in Hanoi in the late 1980s. He also, without specifying names or current positions, levels the accusation of paedophile behaviour against another 15 or so officers of the Department. In all these cases he should give all details in his possession to the Australian Federal Police as a matter of urgency. He should supply all names, evidence and data in his possession. This Department will cooperate to the absolute maximum extent possible in the investigation of any such allegations.

I reject utterly the suggestion by Mr Aldred that the Department is obstructing or attempting to prevent examination of any matters in this regard. We are, and we will continue to take the initiative in examining such matters and ensuring that the police and any other relevant body are involved in a full and complete investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am on my feet, there are two larger issues thrown up by these extraordinary, unsubstantiated and damaging allegations that I think need a little reference. One is the need for us as a parliament to do something more about abuses of privilege. We have done that in the Senate. I do not normally think that what happens in here is a role model for anywhere else, but on this occasion I do draw it to the House of Representatives' attention and say that we ought to do something about making a process available for people outside the parliament who are traduced in this way.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that has to be said is about the role of the press in this particular matter. I think it is time for some sections of the media to take a long, hard look at themselves. If ever there were stories crying out for caution in their treatment, it was these. No doubt they had crude news value, but equally obviously there was potential for the stories to cause enormous damage not only to the officers identified directly by name or by job but to all those SES members who might be thought to be one of the 20 described by Aldred as engaged in paedophile activity. If anything should have made the press profoundly cautious about running the paedophile story in particular, it was it appearing on the same day as the other extraordinary thing about Costello.

I was interested to see a number of papers responding in that responsible way. The West Australian ran neither story; the Australian gave the Costello story a modest page 1 run—it did not mention the paedophile stuff at all; the Melbourne Sun-Herald put Costello on page 2—again, it did not mention paedophiles; a Sydney stablemate, the Daily Telegraph-Mirror, did not run either story—so much for tabloid sensationalism. The Financial Review ran both stories together, again without mentioning the names of any alleged diplomat and did so in an unsensational way. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you clarify your comments further?

—The Courier-Mail ran both stories. It did name the diplomat named by Aldred, but in a quite unsensational way and well back in the paper. I have to say that the papers that did succumb to all the traditional temptations that one associates with tabloids of the sleaziest kind were the so-called quality broadsheets: the Age, the Sydney Morning Herald and, to only a slightly lesser extent, the Canberra Times and the Adelaide Advertiser. The Age ran `paedophiles' as a page 1 lead, under the heading `MP names child sex diplomats' described in the Aldred allegations as explosive and naming prominently the diplomat who was named by Aldred. The Canberra Times again gave the story and the named diplomat front page coverage prominently, as did the Advertiser—although I have to say that its main emphasis was on the Costello story.

PARA.TAB: It was the Sydney Morning Herald that really went to town with its front page story on the paedophile claims, not only naming the diplomat named by Aldred in its lead paragraph but attaching a photograph of him and naming specifically as well a second diplomat who had only been indirectly identified by position in the Aldred speech. Their priority was on sex and sleaze and to hell with the consequences. If they want to command responsibility elsewhere, they ought to occasionally observe their own strictures. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, yesterday you told the Senate that it is the government's desire to make the banking industry more competitive. I remind you of the current situation: the four big banks already control 65 per cent of total assets; banks enjoy margins nearly twice the average of other industrialised countries; and, as we established yesterday, they are not passing on to consumers the one per cent fall in wholesale interest rates. Add to that the fact that the four big banks are starting as favourites to take over Bank WA and the Bank of Melbourne. Do you agree that such a further concentration in the banking markets in Western Australia and Victoria actually limits the opportunity to deliver further competition and the lower interest rates you talked about yesterday? In reality, hasn't the trend since deregulation been towards fewer, bigger banks? And how does this really help deliver those customer services and interest rates that you talked about?

—There are a couple of points that perhaps need to be made on this question. The first one relates to what was in this morning's newspapers. They report a fair bit of competition between the banks over housing loans as they try to position themselves in expectation of how they think the market might move.
—Yes, but mortgages are a tiny, tiny proportion.

—I just note that as a sign of a competitive market. The other point that I think is necessary to be made here is that the finance market is wider than just the banks. While you do make the point about the four majors, what we are seeing is a degree of consolidation of the regional banks. When we see regional banks like the Advance Bank and the Bank of South Australia coming together, we have an entity better able to provide greater competition to the four majors. I think that is a sign of more effective competition in the banks.

PARA.TAB: The third point I make about this is market entry. This is a complex and difficult field to enter, but there are no restrictions on market entry for real competition here and that adds to the wider competitive nature of the financial market. This is a dynamic market. Mergers show that it is dynamic and there are still a number of players which do provide competition between one another. Yesterday I referred to Aussie Home Loans and the AMP Society deciding to extend its operations into home mortgages. They are signs of greater competition. That competition is not just in terms of the headline rate for interest being charged on particular things, but also competition between banking products and the diversity of detail and products offered.

One always wants to see greater competition. It is the government's desire to have a competitive domestic economy. We believe that by doing that we will be able to be more effective, become stronger and become more internationally competitive. But I think we would have to say that, if this question swings on whether some regional banks will consolidate, then the bottom line is that out of that the new entities created will provide far better competition to the big four than they would if they remained separate and regional.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I take it from that, Minister, that the government approves of one of the big four or two of the big four taking over the Bank of Western Australia and the Bank of Melbourne, and what will that mean?
—I do not think you can conclude that from my remarks.

—You don't have to read it, Robert!

—It also recognises that in order to achieve this aim we need to plan for the future. I am sure Senator Kemp will agree with me. Consequently, in March of last year this government launched a national ecotourism strategy. This strategy is the platform for the planning development—

This funding demonstrates that the federal government's ongoing commitment to ensuring—

TALK.START.PARA: —The hand gestures are—

—Yes, I have learnt it off Senator Watson. I have not quite got it right, but I am sure Squeaky will take me aside later. It goes upwards, doesn't it. But don't distract me, because this is a relatively short answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and I ask: Minister, do you acknowledge the importance of the Australia Television service in opening up opportunities for Australia in the Asia-Pacific region and, importantly, as a significant employer in Darwin? Can the government give an unequivocal commitment to the continuation of this service? TALK.START.PARA: —It runs out next month.

So the minister will consider the options canvassed by the ABC concerning ATV satellite transmission costs and bringing forward the scheduled review of ABC international broadcasting services when the detailed proposals are provided by the ABC board.

I cannot add anything more than that at the moment on the basis of the information available to me. If there is something I can add, I will be happy to do it. I share the honourable senator's concern and we will see what we can do to keep it going.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I accept the point the minister makes about his own commitment—and I think a number of us said that at the opening ceremonies of this important facility. But what I am seeking from the government is a long-term commitment to the future of Australia Television, even if it fails to meet its original self-funding objective. In the meantime, I suggest that Senator Tambling gets a similarly unequivocal guarantee from his own party and puts that on the record, because a lot of us would be very interested indeed to know specifically what the commitments of the coalition opposition are going to be to the ABC or, for that matter, to anything else.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to an article in this morning's Australian newspaper where he is reported to have said yesterday on World Environment Day that `Australia must not "naively" endorse tough global environmental rules that could harm its trade position' and that `Australia should not make too many concessions when negotiating international treaties that impose environmental regulations on industry'. How does the Minister propose that Australia can continue to hold its head up high in the international community with policies on treaties which are at odds with almost all other OECD countries, for instance, the stance that Australia took at the recent Berlin conference on greenhouse emissions? Is the government really proposing to be a major contributor to the destruction of this planet's environment by ceasing to take the lead in setting appropriately high standards?

—I wish Senator Chamarette had read a few more quotes from that extract from the Australian this morning because she would have seen clearly laid out there this government's and my personal absolute commitment to those environmental treaties—to making them work and, in particular, to ensuring they are widespread enough and equitable enough in their operation globally to make a difference, in particular in the climate context, to the problems we are all mutually concerned with. One of the points I was making is that there is a problem with potentially inequitable application of the criteria by other developed countries. We have to make sure that we, with our very limited substantive total contribution to the problem, are not treated unfairly in that respect by our fellow trading partners and others in the developed world.

PARA.TAB: I also made the point—and this is something the green movement, both large `G' and small `g', could well take to heart—that if we are going to seriously tackle some of these problems, the developing world has to be part of the solution, not just becoming an ongoing and increasing part of the problem. I did say—what I said was quoted, I think accurately, yesterday—that it would be extraordinarily arrogant and insensitive on the part of developed countries, after the degradation we have wreaked on the environment over 100 years or more, to be making too many outrageously hypocritical demands on our developing country colleagues in this respect. At the same time, the harsh reality is that the numbers are there and, if we are serious about the globe, we have to get the problems being addressed in the developing countries as well.

The problem we confront—and this is the point Senator Faulkner was making very effectively in Berlin—is that the kind of increase we are going to be seeing in additions to the CO(2) and greenhouse gas problem, in particular, is going to be greater from developing countries in the years ahead than the total contribution being made at the moment by the developed world. It is a very serious problem; and it is about time that everyone in the environmental movement started to appreciate the scale of that problem and recognise the need for an unsentimental, hard-headed approach to all dimensions of it.

There is no question about our lack of commitment. On the contrary, we are going to continue to play an important role—and hopefully a leadership role—on these environmental treaty issues, across the whole spectrum of climate, biodiversity, desertification and all the other issues that are dear to the hearts I know of the Australian Democrats and, occasionally, to your hearts in the Green party, although you do not very often behave as if that is the case.

—Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, as you are aware, there are many Australians living in rural and remote areas who are juggling work and family responsibilities. In the light of the Forum for Rural Women being held in Parliament House this week, can you outline the support the government gives these families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to tell the Senate about the rural women's forum, which is being held in Parliament House over the next two days. The forum has been initiated by the Centre for Rural Social Research at the Charles Sturt University and it brings together women from around Australia. Importantly, financial support has been provided by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Office of the Status of Women.

PARA.TAB: About 70 women are attending the forum, including representatives from rural women's groups and governments, journalists, and so on. The main theme is the status of rural women and the needs of all women in rural communities. A particular focus will be on issues affecting women in agriculture. It is believed that there is something like 80,000 women in Australia working as farmers or farm managers, and some further 13,000 working as farm hands and assistants. In broad terms, women represent about 30 per cent of the agricultural work force in this country.

It is also important to recognise the value of off farm work done by women in rural Australia. Certainly, one of the challenges rural women face is the changing perception of their work and what they do. I quote Mary Salce from Victoria at last year's International Women in Agriculture Conference:

ANSWER.PARA: What's the community perception of farm women? They've assumed we're in the kitchen cooking jams and making feather light scones, looking out our country windows at the beauty of the countryside, but in reality we're up to our knees in mud, pulling calves or sitting for days in a sweltering tractor cab harvesting our crops, as well as raising our families.
I suspect that some of the people opposite, particularly my colleague Senator Boswell, would know that these are very real descriptions.

PARA.TAB: I will take up these issues tonight when I address the annual general meeting of Women in Agriculture. I will also be discussing with the group a report by Cathy McGowan, funded by the federal government, called Country Kids—Who Cares?—Child Care—A Work-Related Issue for Farm Families. This report highlights the challenges faced by farming women in their dual roles as partners and mothers. They are worried about the safety and wellbeing of their children, particularly when those children are growing up on farms with animals, machines and chemicals, where all of those pose particular dangers to families.

I am not sure if the Senate is aware of just how dangerous it is to be a child in rural Australia because there is a number of special challenges faced by those families and a number of deaths of children in farming communities due to accidents on farms, to the point where Worksafe Australia has had a specific and particular focus on occupational health and safety for farm families. It is a major concern and it is one of the reasons child care is such an issue of importance for rural families.

This inquiry by Cathy McGowan particularly addressed assistance for rural families. I am pleased to say that now that Victoria has signed the national child-care strategy, innovative places for rural areas may be available. I am looking at ways, and we are already working with the Victorian government, of finding a solution to address the pilot program as proposed by Cathy McGowan's paper.

I thought I might also mention briefly some of the other things we provide for families in rural Australia: mobile children's services, multi-function children's services and, in particular, the recently announced 100 places in all family day care schemes which may be accessed by seasonal workers in rural and remote Queensland. That is already available in Shepparton and other parts of Victoria. Again, it is a very important area of concern for rural families who depend on seasonal work. We are as concerned to assist rural families with child care as we are urban families. We appreciate that child care has to be flexible to meet the different needs of rural families. That is the sort of thing I will be talking about at the conference tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: why does Australia have amongst the highest real interest rates in the OECD?

—There was a long discussion about this in the estimates committee when this question was put to the Secretary of Treasury by, among others, your colleague Senator Short. I do recall that Mr Evans, in discussing the level of long-term interest rates in Australia, did say—referring to the 30-odd public servants sitting behind him—`every one of those may have a different opinion to me but, since this question calls for me to give an opinion, I will express mine'. He then went on to say that the market has not yet weaned itself off the view that Australia is on a long-term, low-inflation course. I do not want to quote him because I cannot recall his words directly but, as I recall what he said, he referred to market behaviour being formed by expectations of high interest rates, that they have not yet realised that we are a low-interest rate economy and that the government is committed to maintaining low interest rates. He then concluded, in the normal way in which Mr Evans gives his views, by saying that that was his view.
—What is your view? Tell us your view.

—I am being interjected upon very strenuously here by Senator Vanstone, among others, demanding to know what my view is. What my view is is not the important thing because I am representing the Treasurer. But I believe that the answer you would get from the Treasurer—and I will check to see if he wants to add to it—would be quite similar to what Mr Evans said. It would include a reference to the market determining these levels of interest rates; working on market expectations of change and performance rather than on government policy.

—Mr Evans, as a good public servant, obviously did not extend his answer to the credibility gap in relation to inflation. But the question is this: the OECD in its recent survey obviously had some difficulty in finding an explanation as to why the real component of the representative nominal bond rate in Australia has risen so substantially since early 1994. Minister, perhaps you can credibly respond to the parliament.
—I am sure I can. I will take it on notice and do so in due course.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During question time Senator Short asked me a question about the level of tax burden. I would like to add to the answer I gave Senator Short. As was explained in parliament last December, the statement made by the Prime Minister in 1992 was that the government would be keeping tax within the tax to GDP ratio of the previous few years. Between 1989-90 and 1991-92 the tax to GDP ratio was between 22.7 per cent and 24.7 per cent. The budget estimates that in 1995-96 tax revenue to GDP will be 24.2 per cent increasing to 24.6 per cent in the 1996-97 years and then declining. The government is therefore meeting its undertaking.

PARA.TAB: Total revenue as a proportion of GDP is estimated to be below that in 1982-83—the last year of the coalition government—and also lower than the average for the 1980s, at a forecast 25.3 per cent in 1995-96 as against 26.1 per cent in 1982-83 and an average 26.4 per cent over the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I was asked a question by Senator Hill concerning R&D tax concessions. He asked how it was that I came into the Senate last week and argued that the finance scheme guidelines were valid when I had gone to the appeal court and argued that they were invalid due to failure to table. I have an answer to that which I am happy to read, but it might be preferable to table it. In any case, I intend to table the documents received by me from my department yesterday afternoon. I have a document of advice headed `Grounds of appeal—legal action in relation to finance scheme advance rulings' which comes from the Attorney-General's Department—Industry, Research and Development Board versus a particular company Federal Court proceeding. I also have a further minute from the Tax Concession Branch of Ausindustry. I intend to table those documents, but perhaps I should have some indication as to whether I should give my full answer or simply table it.
—How long is your full answer?
—It is only a page and a bit.
—It would be good to hear it.

—When I spoke to the Senate last week, to the best of my knowledge, the guidelines were valid. Based on the department's legal advice on how to deal with the discovery that the guidelines had became invalid, the guidelines have been regazetted and were tabled in both houses on 9 and 10 May. The notice of appeal to which the senator refers had been signed off by the Government Solicitor prior to that tabling on 27 April. At that time the guidelines had not yet been tabled, which is why there is reference in that document to the fact that they had no effect in law. The Government Solicitor had been informed—
—That is disgraceful though, isn't it?

—Let me complete the answer, if I may. The Government Solicitor had been informed that, since the conclusion of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal case in question, the department had discovered that the guidelines had become invalid due to an administrative oversight.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has asked me to explain the morality of including the oversight in a notice of appeal. I am happy to do just that. Our legal advice is that, having become aware of the administrative oversight and its impact on the guidelines, it would have been improper not to include it in the notice of appeal. The only allowable means for informing the Federal Court is via the grounds of appeal section of a notice of appeal. I have been informed that there is no other way to do this and that to not do so would constitute unethical behaviour and fraud on the Federal Court.

As to the suggestion that the administrative oversight is being used as a basis of appeal against a private sector litigant, this is a wrong accusation. The appeal in question relates only to the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; it is not an appeal on the merits against a decision in favour of a private sector litigant. The administrative oversight is included in the grounds of appeal for those sound ethical reasons. I table the documents I have referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to incorporate them?
—I am happy to. I seek leave to incorporate those documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: GROUNDS OF APPEAL—LEGAL ACTION IN RELATION TO FINANCE SCHEME ADVANCE RULINGS

To provide advice to you as to the reasons why you were not advised that a Ground of Appeal in relation to the administration of the Tax Concession Program was that the Finance Scheme Guideline was invalid.
On 5 June 1995 you sought advice from me as to why the Department included as a Ground of Appeal in Federal Court Proceeding NG289 of 1995 that:

PARA.TAB: "The Tribunal erred in law in that it held that the Finance Scheme Guidelines were delegated legislation in accordance with Section 39EA of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, notwithstanding that my reason of the operation of Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the same are deemed to have been disallowed, and are of no force or effect in law."

ANSWER.PARA: I have sought advice (Attachment B) from the responsible officer within the Department who was handling this matter and he in turn sought advice (Attachment A) from the Australian Government Solicitor who was engaged in representing the Department. The documents are self-explanatory, they do I consider demonstrate that the officer concerned had a sound basis for authorising the Australian Government Solicitor to proceed in the manner he did.

I also confirm that you had not been advised of this particular of the Grounds of Appeal until today. Indeed, a Minute to you of 2 May 1995 on this matter which sought your approval to proceed with an appeal against the ruling of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal did not indicate that the invalidity of the Guidelines would be a Ground of Appeal.

I also wish to advise you that procedures are now in place which require that any actions or decisions in respect of legislative proceedings in connection with the IR&D Act 1986 or of any legal proceedings related to that Act require my approval prior to proceedings or in the event of my absence, the General Manager of the Tax Concession Branch of AusIndustry.
Noted. Thank you for your Minute.
Why, in view of this advice, however was it not drawn to my attention that this matter would be a ground for appeal?
I note the procedures that have been put in place. I also note that those procedures do not extend to notifying me of appeal grounds in the future.
Please note that I expect me and/or my Officer to be notified of appeal grounds in the future with particular emphasis on drawing our attention to any contentious elements in search and appeal.
Department of Industry Technology and Regional Development
INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD v MARBLO (HOLDINGS) PTY LTD
FEDERAL COURT PROCEEDING NO. NG289 OF 1995

I refer to our telephone conversations this afternoon. I confirm that, in accordance with your instructions, the notice of appeal included the following ground dealing with the failure to table the finance scheme guidelines:-

PARA.TAB: "The Tribunal erred in law in that it held that the Finance Scheme Guidelines were delegated legislation in accordance with Section 39EA of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, notwithstanding that by reason of the operation of Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the same are deemed to have been disallowed, and are of no force or effect in law".

ANSWER.PARA: I confirm the view I have expressed orally on prior occasions that, once it was known that the guidelines had not been tabled and, by reason of the operation of Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, were of no force and effect, it would have been improper to conceal this matter from the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The ground of review was a subject both of counsel's submissions in the Federal Court directions hearing on 23 May 1995 and my letter to the Registrar of the Tribunal dated 25 May 1995 which requested that the matter be drawn to the attention of Deputy President McMahon.
INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD v MARBLO (HOLDINGS) PTY LTD FEDERAL COURT PROCEEDING NO. NG289 OF 1995

I refer to the letter of 5 June from Mr Umberto Torresi of the Australian Government Solicitors Office (at Attachment A) which outlines the basis on which the ground of appeal dealing with the failure to table the finance scheme guidelines arose. This ground was that:-

PARA.TAB: "The Tribunal erred in law in that the Finance Scheme Guidelines were delegated legislation in accordance with Section 39EA of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, notwithstanding that by reason of the operation of Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the same are deemed to have been disallowed, and are of no force or effect in law."

ANSWER.PARA: As noted in para 3 of Mr Torresi's letter, his oral advice conveyed to me was such that I was left with the clear belief that it would be improper not to advise the court and that the appropriate way was to include it as a ground in the appeal.
Indeed his advice to me was such that it was only proper to have so proceeded given that Senior Executive of the Department had taken the decision that the appeal was to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: I only need a couple of minutes. I want to point out how astonishing the explanation is that Minister Cook has just given. He has sought to plead his own default as a basis upon which the court should find in his favour. That is what he has done in this instance. It is really quite amazing. He came in today and argued that it would be unethical not to do so, unethical not to plead his own default as a ground for which he should win the case. Have you ever heard such an amazing argument!

PARA.TAB: What happened in this instance was that the taxpayer bought an action before the AAT and the AAT made a decision, based on the guidelines under the R&D tax concession provisions, against the government. The decision was made against the government. The government then became aware, in fact, that the guidelines were invalid because it, the government, the minister's department, the minister responsible, had failed to table the guidelines. So it went back to the court on appeal and said that now the government should be successful because there are no guidelines in force and the court should therefore find against the taxpayer.

What the minister said today is, `I really had no choice but to do that. This was the interim period between my becoming aware of my default and seeking to take action to overcome that default. Therefore I acknowledge that in that period'—apparently for the first time today—`the guidelines were in fact invalid and I sought to rely on that invalidity.' `To do so,' he said, `would be immoral.' Failure to plead his own default would be immoral and therefore, for sound ethical reasons, he took that absolutely astonishing course of action.

That is appalling! What faith can the ordinary taxpayer have in government in this country when ministers are prepared to act in that way? What sort of fair go are they going to have when ministers rely on their own default to demonstrate invalidity in a guideline and therefore to argue against the taxpayer? This minister should be ashamed that he has come in here today. I can only presume that somebody has written this extra answer for him and he failed to read it before he read it out here today. He should be ashamed of what he has done today. It only compounds his default in this whole sorry saga that we are going to hear a lot about even later today when we seek to get on the public record the relevant documents and start to explore how a default of this consequence could have possibly occurred and how for a year—apparently it was a year before it took any remedial action—the department was aware of the default. This is just another step, but it is a sorry and disappointing step that the minister came in with an answer of that type today.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the level of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred the minister to the infamous promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) before the 1993 election not to put up tax. That is what he said baldly and then he subsequently refined that to say that he would not put up tax as a proportion of GDP. The minister waffled around at great length today and tried to say that what the Prime Minister was saying was that it would stick within the ballpark figure as a percentage of GDP. He claimed that an increase since that statement of 2.1 per cent in the proportion of GDP that the tax takes up is a figure within the range. And 2.1 per cent is more than $10,000 million.

PARA.TAB: So in this year's budget tax is forecast to increase from 22.1 per cent—the figure in the year of the Prime Minister's promise—to 24.2 per cent of GDP this year. That is in excess of $10,000 million—equal to $1,700 per household, or almost $600 for every man, woman and child in Australia. That is the extent of the election deceit and the tax fraud deceit that the Prime Minister rorted on the Australian electorate prior to the 1993 election.

Looking at some of the other figures, there is no doubt at all that this Prime Minister, Mr Keating, is the highest taxing Prime Minister in Australia's history. He is also the Prime Minister who has broken more promises than any Prime Minister in Australia's history. And so far as tax promises are concerned, he is the greatest tax promise fraud in Australia's history. The figures for this budget reveal that in stark terms.

In the financial year just coming up, the government is going to increase its total revenue by $14.2 billion—$14,200 million. Personal income tax is going to go up by almost 10 per cent—almost $14 billion. The total tax take is going to go up by almost $14 billion.

Let us have a look at some of the percentages. In real terms the total income tax take on individuals is going up, so when you take inflation into account, you have to add another three per cent or four per cent on top of that. But even in real terms, after taking out inflation, taxation from individuals is going to rise by a whopping 9.6 per cent. The total sales tax take, after taking out inflation, is going to rise 18 per cent this year. So in dollar terms it is going to be an increase of something like two per cent. The total tax revenue is going to go up by a percentage well over nine per cent.

Indeed, looking at revenue as a whole—tax plus other revenue—for the year just completed, this year and next year combined, we are going to see the greatest tax revenue increase since the infamous Whitlam budgets of the 1970s which absolutely wrecked the Australian economy. The great danger that underlies this present budget is that we are going to see a repeat of yet more of those disastrous policy failures that we saw under the Whitlam government which took years and years, if ever, to correct in the Australian economy and which are sowing the seeds for major future damage of the Australian economy. It is an absolute disgrace for the government to be so complacent about the economic and tax situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Christopher Evans this day, relating to an industrial dispute in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Labor Party's performance on the waterfront and shipping reform. A lot of light, noise and heat have been developed—by Senator Collins in particular, when he was the minister. His activities in the area culminated with the now famous meeting with then Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Senator Collins giving funny interjections about getting lung cancer because Prime Minister Hawke smoked so many cigars that night. We all remember Senator Collins saying he would resign if he did not reform the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: The reality for Australia, for its exporters and importers and, therefore, for Australian consumers, is that Australia's waterfront has not improved compared with the situation of our trading partners and competitors. What the Western Australian dispute is about—and it needs to be stated, because I believe Senator McMullan misrepresented it and used his ideological blinkers to put his ideological spin on the facts around the dispute in Western Australia—is that the Western Australian Stateships organisation and the managers of that organisation, whom I do not know, sought to ensure that the most competitive quote from a stevedoring company won; and was used to provide that service to Stateships.

Senator McMullan has come into this place on many occasions when I have asked him questions about Commonwealth owned business entities and said that they must be independent and must behave in a competitively neutral way that ensures that they do not compete unfairly against the private sector. He is now coming in and saying that Stateships should not be allowed to enter into a contractual obligation with a stevedoring company. The person in this chamber with the ideological blinkers on in this dispute is Senator McMullan. I also suspect Senator Chris Evans, but I will not accuse him of that because his views are not yet on the record.

Stateships or any other state organisation or quasi-government business enterprise cannot go out into the marketplace and say that it needs services provided—in this case, it is a shipping company—and then look at the tenders, contracts and bids. Stateships chose a company which I understand is owned by Len Buckeridge. This company employs non-union labour.

The union monopoly in Western Australian ports, particularly in Fremantle, has ensured that, regardless of the commercial nature of a negotiation between Stateships and the stevedoring company owned by Mr Buckeridge, it cannot be done. It is not a free world when you enter the ports of Western Australia; it is a closed world. We go back to an old world where there is a monopoly. Regardless of the democratically elected government or the contractual obligations and negotiations between commercial entities, being Stateships on the one hand and a stevedoring company on the other, the trade union movement was prepared to close down the ports of Western Australia because it was not happy with the situation.

In other words, any agreement that is done in a port in Western Australia must get the approval of the unions that operate on awards in Western Australia. It is like getting an agreement and taking it down to the stamp office when stamp duty is paid. It is not an agreement until the state stamp duty is paid on it. In the ports in Western Australia, one has to get the unions in the workplace to do that.

The sad thing about that is that ultimately Western Australia is held to ransom. The business interests of Western Australia said to Richard Court, the premier, `You have to get this sorted out. You are killing us.' But it was not the government or the premier that was killing business; it was the trade unions. This handful of people have had their special place in legal affairs in Australia enshrined by this federal Labor government. They have a position at the bargaining table even when they are not part of the bargain. They are prepared to hold to ransom the whole of Western Australia until they get their way.

This is a disgraceful set of affairs. This government has stood by the trans-Tasman accord, which has meant that shipping between Australia and New Zealand is far more expensive than it needs to be. It stands by a system of cabotage, which ensures that coastal shipping in Australia is far more expensive than it needs to be. It has created a waterfront monopoly that is very little better than it was in the early 1980s. We still have the most expensive waterfronts in the world. That costs Australia's consumers. That reform is crucial if Australia is to create opportunities for people to gain employment in this place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to sales tax on building materials.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ian Macdonald's question highlights the fact that the Australian people have been misled in terms of the impact of the sales tax on building hardware. Budget paper No. 1 indicates that the government will extend the wholesale sales tax to building materials. But the government and the budget papers have not told us that the wholesale sales tax will not only apply to materials but also, in many cases, to the labour component and to oncosts, particularly in the joinery workshop. Even the honourable Senator Murphy has been misled by the government's propaganda on this. If in doubt, I ask him to refer to the Australian Taxation Office or any joinery workshop. One could be completely misled in relation to this matter by the budget papers.

PARA.TAB: Take, for example, the ordinary joiner who completes a cupboard arrangement to put into a new home. If prepared in the joinery shop, this may have to have sales tax applied to the material content added value. Then there is a cost allocation problem between certain of the material which he might buy as green timber and other timber which the joiner processes through cutting and planing on the job in the joinery. The joinery then adds labour cost and also factory service cost.

This means, of course, that there is a major problem, because the work done in the joinery is going to have the sales tax applicable to the labour content in addition to maybe some of the materials—if not all of the materials—depending on their origin and how the component parts are put together. It is no use shaking your head, Senator Murphy—the sales tax does apply to the labour cost of gluing and fixing and putting together in the joinery shop. That is well understood and has been confirmed by all appropriate authorities. However, this is not stated in these budget papers, and could be where there is a discrepancy between Senator Cook's sales tax estimate and the figure Senator Schacht provided.

We all know—ask any joinery around town—whose figure is more correct, and it will certainly be in the order of $1,000 or more. That is the figure that Senator Schacht has quoted. The figure for sales tax on hardware that is in the budget papers is hopelessly inadequate for a normal family home and shows the inability of the government to get down and consult with reality—the people who produce the cupboards for the kitchens and bathrooms.

This hardware sales tax extension is going to create all sorts of tax audit difficulties between the tax office and the small joinery shop, because, for instance, there is no sales tax on the installation costs in the home. Therefore, the shonky builders will take all their basic materials along to the client's home and try to construct the kitchen or bathroom renovation there and argue, `This is an installation cost, thereby avoiding sales tax. It is not a joinery cost.' There will be problems of avoidance compliance—

TALK.START.PARA: —Massive compliance costs.

—A massive problem with compliance costs, because all small joinery shops will inevitably be subject to tax audit in relation to these demarcation issues. It is true that the installation costs are not going to be subject to sales tax, whereas the costs of putting work together in the joinery shop will be subject to sales tax. It is in the joinery operation where cost efficiencies occur—not in putting the fixture together in the client's home.

PARA.TAB: If a client orders a kitchen package off the shelf, it has a 12 per cent tax applied on the wholesale or the nominal wholesale price including labour. Admittedly, there are not a lot of builders who engage in this particular type of activity, but there are some—and it is usually the larger ones. Again, this whole activity has the sales tax applicable not only to the material components—the nails and the screws and the bolts, as we were led to believe—but also to the labour components other than for installation.

I put it to you that we are going to have a new era of backyard builders doing renovation work, doing it outside tax audit verification paperwork, and with a lack of disclosure to the tax office in terms of non-disclosure for income tax purposes. We are going to see a situation of backyarders doing the job and not reporting their income as required. So the government is actually creating a situation of potential tax avoidance. This government believes it has a credible record in trying to wipe out the cash economy. However, I tell you here and now that the government has introduced something in this budget that is going to create a massive problem in terms of the black economy and is going to result in a lot of honest builders losing their jobs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling this day, relating to funding for the Australian Corporation's Australia Television.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorry saga of Australia Television International joins that stable of other nobbled horses of David Hill, who was the Managing Director of the ABC and innovator in the area of ABC products and programs. We have already seen, within a period of three months since a major inquiry into the ABC earlier this year, a number of David Hill's innovations to commercialise ABC operations go belly up.

PARA.TAB: We had the case of BNA—Broadcast News Australia—which was set up as a rival to AAP. Three months ago it had glowing prospects for the future but now the government is about to wind it up. In his answer today the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) mentioned the prospect of Australia Television International also being in huge difficulties and facing, as one alternative, the possibility of being wound up. One waits with some trepidation to see the fate of pay TV, another venture into the commercial world by the ABC. The prospects of pay TV are under some sort of a cloud given the ABC's track record on commercial operations.

Under David Hill's stewardship we have seen a great change in the way in which the ABC operates. In an attempt to get extra revenue, the ABC has moved into a whole range of fringe activities, largely driven by the great enthusiasm of David Hill and not by any sort of commercial sense or preparedness to operate these commercial ventures.

I would like to focus on Australia Television International. I believe we would all support the concept that we should have a showcase for Australia in the Asia Pacific region. Australia Television International had the potential to do that but the government went about it in a ham-fisted way and put the future of the project in great jeopardy.

Initially, the government tried to fund Australia Television International with a seed capital of $5.4 million—which was obviously greatly inadequate—and make up the rest by commercial sponsorship. The marketing program was grossly inadequate in trying to work out whether it had markets and audiences. Sponsorships were supposed to be the main mechanism of finance. While they have not gone down significantly, they have certainly not fulfilled their projections.

Probably the greatest worry for the parliament is where the whole operation goes from here. One of the rather disturbing options that came out of the Senate hearings was the idea of combining the whole thing with Radio Australia. The danger in doing that is that we are combining a charter core activity, which is funded under the ABC budget, with a commercial activity which is supposed to be in the main funded by commercial sponsorship.

The cultures of the two organisations are quite incompatible and the government should think very carefully if it is to go down this track. At hearings of estimates committees the government was a little coy about this. I suggest to the government that it might consider a different option altogether. It should declare Australia Television International part of the core activity of the ABC and fund it properly with a $4 million injection per year. SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people are not satisfied with the government's handling of health; nor should they be. Bearing in mind that each percentage point fall represents $100 million extra burden on the public health system, the situation is at crisis point.

The present Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, is attempting to rescue the public health system by increasing the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent and, in doing so, has broken another Labor promise. This government's reforms have failed low and middle income earners, the very people that the Labor Party claims to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that Commonwealth Bank officers were not in attendance to answer questions at the estimates hearings of the Economics Legislation Committee in June 1995, in spite of the significant public interest in the employment and other implications of the bank's decisions; and

(b)directs that Mr Ian Payne, Executive Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, attend the supplementary estimates hearing of the Economics Legislation Committee to answer questions concerning the bank's staffing and headquarters arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: At the estimates hearings last week I gave notice that I wished Commonwealth Bank officers to attend the hearing to answer questions relating to staffing matters and headquarter arrangements at the Commonwealth Bank. I gave due notice and heard nothing from the government or the bank until, at the committee hearing, I was informed by Senator Cook that the Commonwealth Bank officers were not in attendance and, rather, that Treasury officers would be available to answer questions relating to the Commonwealth Bank.

PARA.TAB: Treasury officers duly appeared. The first question I asked was: what is the current staffing level at the Commonwealth Bank? No-one had any idea. The Treasury officers were clearly not briefed to answer questions; nor were they prepared to answer questions.
The standing orders of the Senate make very clear that this chamber has the right to direct attendance of persons and documents at legislative committee hearings. Standing order 19(9) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee and any sub-committee shall have power to send for persons and documents, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session—
The standing order goes on. We have the right to require Commonwealth Bank officers to attend an estimates committee hearing and the standing orders of the Senate make that absolutely clear.

PARA.TAB: In fact, in the past, of course, the Commonwealth Bank has appeared. The last time that I can recall that happening was in June 1993. Honourable senators might ask: why an estimates hearing and not perhaps a more general and special reference to a Senate committee? The answer is that these are issues which I believe relate to staffing and headquarters matters. They are matters which are of public interest and it is appropriate that these issues be raised before an estimates committee, given the huge level of investment of the Commonwealth in that particular bank, even though the government in due course intends to privatise the bank.

Of course, ministers are worried about it. Unlike at an ordinary meeting of a Senate committee, the minister will be in attendance. Senator Cook is looking confused. As it happens to be an estimates committee hearing, the minister will be in attendance, and that provides, I suspect, some comfort for the officers of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very opposite.

—Yes, it does. That provides some comfort for the officers of the Commonwealth Bank about the nature of the questions which will be asked. I put it to the Senate that this would never have arisen if the Commonwealth Bank had continued with the practice it had over the previous two or three years and provided me with clear-cut answers as to precisely what is happening to employment levels at the bank.

PARA.TAB: I have a particular interest in this because I am a Victorian. It is very clear that there have been massive retrenchments of Commonwealth Bank officers in that state and a large number—some hundreds, maybe up to 1,000—of forced redundancies. I am anxious to put straightforward questions to the bank—not to intrude into any issues of commercial-in-confidence but to put straightforward questions to the bank as to precisely what is happening with its staffing arrangements and what has happened in the past—so that the public can be aware of the consequences of this particular bank merger and the people who are Commonwealth Bank officers will have the chance to feel that the Commonwealth parliament is starting to address the very real concerns that they have.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the standing orders make it quite clear that the Senate has the right to require the presence of Commonwealth Bank officials at an estimates hearing. For the sensitivities of those opposite who may be worried that somehow this will lead to an abuse of the system, Commonwealth bank officers have appeared before Senate committees before but, in this particular case, they will have the additional protection of a minister being in attendance.

I am not interested in pursuing matters which are commercial-in-confidence. I am interested in finding out the precise facts of what has happened with the staffing arrangements in the bank. I believe the motion is responsible. The need for it would not have arisen had the Commonwealth Bank continued with the practice it was prepared to follow until recent months and supplied me with information on this matter.

I hope the Senate will pass this motion. We will be requiring the attendance of Commonwealth Bank officers at the estimates hearing. The government will be arguing that it is an independent organisation, but it is not a matter in the end for the government. The government cannot argue on the one hand that the bank is an independent bank and, on the other hand, instruct the bank not to appear before a Senate estimates committee. That is a dilemma that Senator Robert Ray will have to effectively address.

To summarise, this motion would never have arisen had the Commonwealth Bank been prepared to answer questions which have been answered before, particularly those relating to the staffing levels at the bank. In the context of questions at Senate estimates committee, I am prepared to respect the issues which are commercially sensitive, but there is no argument, either for the government or for the bank, to rule out questions which may be politically sensitive.

The Commonwealth Bank, I believe—and the figures demonstrate this—has got itself into one awful mess in Victoria. It has in an arrogant way been carrying out a massive restructuring of the bank without properly taking the public into its confidence and involving itself in compulsory retrenchments of workers, quite contrary to the promises that were given by Mr Keating and, at the time of the merger, the assurances given by the Commonwealth Bank.

As there is an informal agreement to keep this debate fairly short, I put it to the Senate that this is a responsible motion. It is a motion that will ensure that there are proper protections available to the Commonwealth Bank officers. At the same time, it will ensure that the Commonwealth Bank officers and the Commonwealth Bank answer valid questions to the Senate as to precisely what is happening with the staffing arrangements at that bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear that I have no objection to the Commonwealth Bank appearing before that committee. My objection lies in their appearing in the estimates process. The estimates process is about expenditure of government money and the accountability of it; ministers sit at the table and answer the questions—presumably only about the current financial year. But with a degree of agreement and tradition, we let those questions develop right across the line into a whole range of policy areas, quite properly. That is the tradition. What Senator Kemp is doing today is setting a new precedent. He is saying that government businesses enterprises, whatever their nature, should appear in the estimates process.
—No.

—That is what you are saying. You are saying that a government business enterprise whose employees are not public servants should be brought before the estimates committee and be cross-examined. I say to you, Senator Kemp: if you want to talk to the Commonwealth Bank about all its plans, do it in the context of its annual report to this parliament. Then, quite properly, you can ask exactly the same questions. I am sure no-one is going to object to your asking those questions—with no minister present—because they have to report and be responsible to this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Things are not the same with the Commonwealth Bank now as they may have been five years ago. The bank is now 49 per cent owned by shareholders. So you want to bring non-public servants into a process that traditionally has ministers and public servants, and cross-examine them in that context when they have got responsibilities under such things as the Companies Act. It is no use saying at this stage, Senator Kemp, that you want to quarantine this. I believe you want to, but I have also seen the way things start to move out.

My view is that you are entitled to cross-examine the Commonwealth Bank in the context of its annual report. You can do it any month of the year—you can do it tonight, you can do it next week—and you can use your powers on a Senate committee to bring whoever you want to into the room and ask them whatever questions you want. Obviously, if you stray into those areas of commercial-in-confidence, you will not get an answer. Let me tell you this: no minister is going to be mug enough to sit in the same room and take total responsibility for the veracity of arguments and evidence that they do not have any fundamental responsibility for. If some officer, be it of the Commonwealth Bank or of some other GBE, misleads, why should a minister be responsible when they are not within his employ?

For heaven's sake! You are setting a precedent here that you are going to live to regret. You have an easy opportunity to get exactly the answers you want. What you are doing is picking the wrong process—you are picking the estimates committee process rather than the powers those committees have been generously granted under consideration of annual reports. You might say that standing orders say that that is a mistake, frankly. In my view, that is a translation—because of the restructuring of the committee system—that left powers in that were never conceived, or believed, to apply to estimates committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —You passed them.

—Yes, I did. I remember that I was also involved in all the discussions around the restructuring of the committee system—all of them. It was made clear by us that Senate estimates committees did not have the power to bring witnesses. Leaving that aside, what you are doing today is saying that a minister in an estimates committee process has to have sitting next to him witnesses whom he does not employ. If you expect the minister to then be responsible for the answers they give, when he has no power to know whether they are true or false or otherwise, you are setting a very bad precedent.
