The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—The President has received the following letter, dated 6 June 1995, from Senator Coulter:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Government:

PARA.TAB: (a)to recognise the comprehensive importance of science;
(b)to fund basic and strategic scientific research adequately; and
(c)to comprehend the continuing need for strong Government support for public interest research.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Yours sincerely,
John Coulter
Is the proposal supported?

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Government:

PARA.TAB: (a)to recognise the comprehensive importance of science;
(b)to fund basic and strategic scientific research adequately; and
(c)to comprehend the continuing need for strong Government support for public interest research.

SPEECH.PARA: Science in Australia is in a very parlous state as a direct consequence of the attitude and policies of this Labor government. Without a rapid and significant change in this attitude it is clear that basic and strategic scientific research will continue to decline in amount and quality thus removing the very base on which much of our applied research depends. Even more importantly, the role of science as a cultural building block of a scientifically literate society will be further weakened.

PARA.TAB: As more of the senior scientists in our universities and institutes reach retirement age, the quality of science in Australia will deteriorate more quickly and we will reach a stage from which it will be very difficult to recover.

The fundamental fault with this government is that it has conceived many activities which have a wide social context, such as education and scientific research—and, one might add, even the arts—merely as elements in its economic program. Education is about more than shaping the human cogs to fit into an economic rationalist's dream of his perfect but mechanistic and inhuman world. Science is about more than being the handmaiden of a more productive industry and, like the arts and general education, is about the creations and satisfactions of the human spirit and the understanding of the world in which we live.

This is not to say that education, science and the arts have no place to play in economic life or profitability, they do, but it is to say that their importance extends far beyond this narrower focus and to attempt, as the government has done, to confine these activities in this way is to lose much of their value. Paradoxically, the spontaneous and the creative, the serendipitous, provide the wellspring from which the applied and the technically profitable derive. Thus these elements which have become so neglected under this government are the very elements which will continue to sustain the technological efforts of Australian industry in the future.

I want to stress this point at the beginning, for debates like this tend to bog down very quickly in details about funding and on how many dollars are spent here and there and the general context in which these matters tend to become lost. I am sure the minister will attempt, in his contribution, to avoid this important philosophical point and will attempt to smother the debate with numbers of dollars. So this addresses the first point in the urgency debate this afternoon.

Perhaps just one indicator of the very low status given to science by this government is that on budget night several weeks ago the computers in our parliamentary offices were provided with over four megabytes of information on the budget at exactly 8 p.m. immediately after the budget speech had concluded. This material consisted of nine files, the contents of two of which were not immediately available. A quick search—and one of the advantages of computers is that you can do this—of this four megabytes of material contained not a single mention of science. The word science did not appear once in any of that material. And, incidentally, the word environment appeared only once in relation to the natural environment.

Turning now to some of the figures: it is estimated that Australia spends approximately 1.3 per cent of its GDP on scientific research. I know the government will try to maintain that the figure is 1.5 per cent, but this depends on allocating an arbitrary percentage of higher education funding to research.

It is doubtful whether the percentage used can be supported. For while the total amount going into higher education has increased since the Australian Labor Party came to government in 1983, the numbers of students have risen at a faster rate, so the amount available per student has actually declined and the pressure on university lecturers and research scientists has resulted in less money and time for research.

Talk to any university lecturer in science and this is precisely what you will find. According to the Australian vice-chancellors, in 1991 the per capita student allocation in universities had fallen 11 per cent compared with 1983 and was still eight per cent less in 1993. It was 10 per cent less than it was in 1975. Thus the percentage of funds available out of this pot specifically for research from the higher education allocation is certainly less than the arbitrary 30 per cent, which is the figure that I am sure the government will shortly use.

The lack of quality in student education combined with the emphasis on personal competition, material acquisitiveness and the lack of a clear career path for scientists has resulted in a fall in the quality of students entering science.

Comparison of the entry scores of students into 36 Australian universities shows that while medicine attracts the best students, science is among the least attractive. On a scale of one to five in which one is the highest, medicine scored one in every university while science did not score one in a single university. In other words, we have not a single university in this country with a reputation in science so high that it attracts the best students. Put another way, while medicine takes 99.8 per cent of its students from the upper quartile and none from the lower quartile, science takes only 22 per cent from the upper quartile and 24 per cent from the lowest. On the one to five scale, averaged across all universities, science scored 4.2, only marginally above nursing which scored the lowest at 4.5.
The poorer entry of students into science, lack of funding and lack of emphasis on fundamental, basic and strategic research have resulted in a fall in the relative science citation rate.

Paul Burke and Linda Butler of the Research School of Social Sciences at the Australian National University published a monograph last year called A crisis for Australian science. The paper considers the rate of science of publication and citation for Australian scientists for the period 1982-91. They explain that they were led to this study by the publication in the American journal Science watch of figures which showed a decline in the impact of Australian scientific publication as measured by science in the indices of the Institute of Scientific Information.

One measure of the output of scientific research is the number of papers published. However, the quantity of published papers varies widely and a much better measure of productivity is the rate of citation of papers. This is the number of times that other scientists quote a published paper; that is, its use of results to build on to their own output. A paper which breaks new ground and opens new fields for inquiry may be cited many hundreds of times by later workers, whereas one that fills a relatively trivial corner of an established discipline may be cited only a few times or not at all. The citation rate is thus a direct measure of the quality and importance of science and of the published work.

Burke and Butler show that, while Australia's share of world scientific publications fell marginally in 1992-93 from 1.95 per cent to 1.9 per cent, our share of citations fell more steeply from 1.95 per cent to 1.55 per cent and that this was especially steep in the years 1988-91. In other words, there has been a very steep decline in the quality of Australian science since 1987.

Based on a calculated relative citation index, these authors showed that, averaged across all disciplines, there has been an eight per cent decline in the index—but with a wide variation between disciplines. When asked about this decline, some witnesses at our CSIRO inquiry last year pointed out that this may be due to the fact that more of their work was directed towards local problems. However, in the agricultural area, Australia's work has held up quite well.

Returning very briefly to funding, one finds that Australia spends relatively small amounts on its science. While the ratio of government to private funding favours the government, compared with that in many other countries, the absolute amount as well as the amount expressed as a percentage of GDP does not compare favourably with that in many other countries. Non-government spending on research has been growing strongly in recent years, but from a very small base. Government has not recognised that most of the very large firms in Australia are foreign and conduct most of their research overseas.

The US Congress, late last year, adopted a science appropriation budget of 2.6 per cent of GDP, exactly twice that of Australia. One might remark, in passing, that South Korea has a budget of five per cent of GDP, which it spends on science. Compared with a number of other countries, we are not performing well in terms of our expenditure, the education of our scientists, the opportunities given to science or the amount of basic and strategic research which is being conducted in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to defend the government's record and, somewhat bemusedly, to try to comprehend what Senator Coulter is driving at. The record, as he should know, does not support the contentions of his motion. He says in his opening remarks that science in Australia is in a parlous state due to the government; but the government is not guilty as charged. Let me not rely on my own assertions to establish that fact. I turn to the 18 May edition of the international science journal Nature in which Sir John Maddox, in his review of Australia's science after a recent visit to our shores, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The general conclusion is that Australian science is in good shape . . . Australia may at last have found the right arrangements for the management of publicly supported research . . . industrial research spending has been growing quickly, more quickly than in any other OECD country.
In another journal, New Scientist, also a benchmark magazine for scientists, its review of Australia stated:

If you take any of the conventional measures of scientific excellence, whether it be numbers of Nobel prize winners, scientific papers published, citations per paper, heads of international conferences, and so on, then Australia does extremely well for its GNP and population.
To go back further, New Scientist stated:
It is a pity . . . Australians . . . seem never to have felt too good about their own scientific prowess, even though it is widely recognised abroad.

It is not the government but the international science community which is passing judgment on the level of science in Australia. By any measure, it is a testimony to a government which is switched on to this subject and is performing well. It is something that Australians, as a community, should be proud of.

PARA.TAB: The other cheap shot in Senator Coulter's opening remarks was the reference to budget night. He said that on 9 May, budget night—a Tuesday—there was no reference in the budget to science. Senator Coulter, you would know that the document I am now waving in the Senate was tabled on the Thursday after budget. It is a statement by me, as the responsible minister. It is headed, `Science and Technology: budget statement 1995-96.' It runs to over 180 pages. It was not out on budget night but it was out on the Thursday after, in the normal manner of these things. That paper is a comprehensive statement of the government's position on science. Dare I say that it was a cheap shot to say it was not given on the night. You omitted to tell the chamber that it was given two days later and was comprehensive, stand alone, and open to criticism and analysis.

One of the reasons the government cannot be condemned in the way the motion proposes is that it is now public knowledge, and has been for many months, that we intend to bring down a major statement which will address science and technology capacity in this nation. We intend to do that in August or September this year under the heading `Innovation Statement'. We have had over a thousand consultations about it with leading companies, organisations and individuals around Australia in all capital cities and major provincial centres. We have published a book reporting all of the input. The major organisations consulted and the science community are manifold but I cite particularly the CSIRO and the Academy of Science. Both have been consulted and both have given their views.

Senator Coulter may know that we are going to have further consultations on particular matters in relation to what this motion refers to. At the annual dinner of the Academy of Science I was moved to observe—it was an observation, not a criticism—that the content of the innovation statement, in terms of what scientists had been able to put forward, was still a bit light on from the science community and I asked scientists to please consider what further information they could provide.

When we hear talk about lack of government commitment we can cite the international arbitrators, the journals that comment on world science quality and excellence. We can look at what we have done in the budget. In Senator Kernot's response to the budget and in the response by Senator Hill, the shadow minister for science, on the Thursday following the budget, neither Senator Kernot nor Senator Hill mentioned the subject of science. That may be some indication of the priority that both the parties, which seem hell-bent on condemning our government for its record, assign to the issue of science. No-one chose to mention the subject on the very day we had put down this 180-page document saying what our record was; and what the future goals were.

Everyone knew we were committed to bringing down a major statement on innovation, dealing with science and technology in Australia. It is on the public record that on many occasions I have clearly said, and I clearly state it now in the context of this motion, that Australia—and the government of Australia, as long as we are in power—is committed to proper expenditure on long-term fundamental research in this country and to developing a very active and strong applied research community. That has been the goal. We are moving towards it and we are delivering on it.

How do I know that? Let me go to another international arbiter of performance by countries. We are a member of the OECD. What has it said in its most recent figures? Referring to GERD, gross expenditure on research and development—an index the OECD keeps and which includes scientific expenditure—Australia has moved up in the list of OECD countries from, as I recall, 16th to 13th on overall expenditure in the economy, as ranked in the OECD on research and development.

But what is the government's proportion of that expenditure? At a time when the states have reduced expenditure on research development, including long-term fundamental research, the government has moved from a position in the OECD rankings of sixth to fourth. We have leapt over a number of other countries. We now have only three countries ahead of us in terms of total public sector expenditure on research and development.

Is that a record of which not to be proud? Is that not an indication of the direction of change that this government is proposing to take in research and development? Of course it is. On those clear figures, it is idle—in fact, it is improper—to criticise the government's performance. I would have thought that, with his reputation and standing in the science community, Senator Coulter would be praising that performance and holding it up as a shining example. Perhaps he would even be attending an estimates committee from time to time and putting the CSIRO scientists under scrutiny to see how, for their part, they are delivering on this sort of expenditure.

I cannot conclude the presentation on the OECD statistics without referring to the private sector. Frankly, a lot of poor comment has been made about the private sector's performance. It is true that the private sector was ranked 17th overall in the OECD on research and development expenditure. It moved up because, in the private sector in the last two OECD years, Australia increased expenditure by 28 per cent. That is a major increase in the private sector. It has moved up to the ranking of 16th. The direction of change is for further improvement to be captured and made. The private sector needs to be commended on that.

It needs to be recognised that we are undergoing massive economic restructuring in this country. A key element of that economic restructuring has been building a manufacturing and services base for this economy so that we are not entirely reliant on agricultural and mining exports and we have a manufacturing dimension. Every economy in the world that is ahead of us on private sector expenditure on R&D is a major manufacturing or services economy. These things go together. Where there is major manufacturing, there is major research and development. As we are evolving a manufacturing base, so are we evolving higher levels of private sector expenditure on research and development.

But the motion goes back to our performance. While we are talking about figures, it is worthwhile comparing the Labor government's expenditure on research and development with the expenditure of the previous Liberal government in this area. It is worthwhile because voters may make a decision about this. In real terms, expenditure by this government is 67 per cent higher than the same level of expenditure under the previous Liberal government. That is, expenditure has increased in real terms by 67 per cent under us compared with under the Liberals. In dollar terms, $1.7 billion more in real money is available to Australian science under us than was available under the previous Liberal government.

Basic long-term research, the subject of this urgency motion today, increased in that period by 62 per cent in real terms. Condemnation of the government obviously involves massive condemnation of the opposition, if the motion is to be held to be true. Therefore, if the opposition votes for it, it will be condemning itself by way of extending the principle that it has put. If it does, it will need to explain that. Senator Hill will be speaking next; he may be able to do it. He is quite an articulate spokesperson, but it may well be beyond his capable articulation to explain how the performance of the previous Liberal government, which is 62 per cent poorer than ours, is somehow to be held up as a shining example.

In the moment left to me, one of the other issues covered in Senator Coulter's comments today is students and the attraction of science for students in the Australian system. We have been conducting a major science awareness program around Australia. I hope that we can continue to expand it in the future to encourage students to see the virtue of scientific study. It is wrong to criticise performance by where the benchmark tests are set in terms of entry levels. Look at the top 10 per cent of all students at Australian universities. Twenty-five per cent of them are studying science and technology issues. Irrespective of entry level qualifications, a high level of the very best students go into this discipline. Senator Coulter should look at that figure. (Time expired)

It is important that the debate take place in the parliament, because we all have a responsibility to communicate to the Australian public not only the extent of the government's shortcoming in this area but also how critical to the future prosperity, security, wellbeing and quality of life of all Australians the issue of science and technology is.

PARA.TAB: This area has not received sufficient priority not only from this government but from governments that have preceded it. To that extent, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), in seeking to address the past, had some basis for expressing concern. This country as a whole has understated the importance of science and technology to our future. It is time that we redress that issue.

Senator Coulter raised the issue of the profile of science in the eyes of the government. The best way to assess that is really where the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other senior ministers put science. We can see how they assess their priorities by their major speeches. How many major speeches have we heard from the Prime Minister on the issue of science? We hear him talking about his dream of a republic, Australia in Asia and various other things. But do we ever hear him talking about the importance of science to the future of this country?

Do we ever see him laying down his blueprint for a future prosperous Australia based on the use of the highest quality science and technology? No-one ever hears that. Go back to the years of his predecessor, Mr Hawke. I can remember his so-called famous science speech in 1989. From the image of this government in the community, we can see at a glance that science and technology does not rate highly. If we can do something from a parliamentary perspective to change that, that is for the good.

Look at the priority of the government in terms of its outlay of funding. In the last budget, for example, science and technology funding declined by 0.4 per cent in real terms. Look at CSIRO, our foremost scientific institution. It is a body of which we all should be proud for its record in the past and achievements for the benefit of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —Are you opposing that?
—Senator Schacht did not listen to me. I said that I am not knocking it. I am saying that it is a demonstration of the priority of the Prime Minister. One can only assess—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht never listens. One can only assess the priority this government sets by the priority the Prime Minister applies to his funding decisions. We know that this is a one-man government, so we need look only at the priorities of the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I will go on. If you look at the Australian Institute of Marine Science—something that Senator Schacht did his best to wreck when he was the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science for a short period before he was removed from that position in disgrace—you will see that in the last budget the government's expenditure on this institute declined by 3.2 per cent in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is so good, we will stop.

PARA.TAB: If you just look at the economic consequences of this failure and the high-tech areas, you will see how so much of our balance of payments deficit is being made up from our failure to manufacture and to produce—let alone to export in the high-tech areas. —I was explaining my reasons for my opposition to this proposal. It is a complete waste of time that we have seen from the opposition parties in recent times. I was demonstrating the factual errors of this proposal in that it is presumed that the Commonwealth is not doing enough in terms of science, yet the evidence presented by the minister, both before the estimates committees and in this parliament, firmly demonstrates the commitment of the Australian government, in terms of dollars and in policy commitment, towards making sure that Australia builds a very strong scientific base, both in the public sector and in the private sector.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a 67 per cent increase in funding since this government came to office. We have seen major commitments given in terms of the way in which we have approached higher education, which is the basis of our scientific research in this country and, of course, is unique in terms of the way in which research sectors are performing in providing additional support to industry and to the country at large.

We have seen in the statement made by this government recently, the science and technology budget statement, an increase of 314 per cent in funding over an 11-year period. We have seen, in the support provided to university operating grants, a 40 per cent increase in the last 11 years. So we can see in a whole range of areas that we have major commitments from this government. We have seen, in terms of the government contribution to R&D, that we are now the fourth country in the OECD. We are ahead of Germany, Japan, and, of course, the United States.

However, the only policy we have seen from the opposition is that it wants to cut $10 billion from the budget. That would mean, in real terms, an effective cut of 10 per cent in the budget outlays translated for science, which is $360 million. We would see a $134 million cut over a triennium from the CSIRO if that sort of policy were implemented. We would see a $62 million cut in terms of the Australian Research Council. What do we see from the opposition? In reality, it makes no commitment. It has no policy other than the broad statement that it would like to see a further $10 billion cut from the budget outlay. We will not adopt such an irresponsible attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps if Senator Carr had been at estimates last Thursday night he would have known just how little the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, did tell us because he seemed to go to great lengths to tell us nothing when he was explaining the government's science policy. Whilst I might not always agree with Senator Coulter's political views, I must say that no one in this place doubts his credentials or his expertise in the area of science. I am very pleased to be able to support the motion today because there is no doubt in my mind that this government has failed to recognise—to use Senator Coulter's words—the `comprehensive importance of science'. That phrase is very important.

PARA.TAB: This minister and this government give the apparent view that they could not care less about science and technology. We hear a lot of words about what the government is doing for science, but in reality it is not promoting science and technology. The government does not talk it up. Those opposite can table all the books they like in this place, but there is no lead from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) down in talking up science and technology.

The government does not seem to appreciate the incredible opportunities that are there for the taking for nations which are scientifically and technologically advanced. The government has done nothing to create a science culture in Australia. There is no way in which the government could be seen to be publicly promoting science as the way forward for Australia. While our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region are forging ahead in science and technology, spending more than we do on R&D, the government has cut CSIRO's funding, put the squeeze on university research and failed spectacularly to kick-start the private sector R&D.

I think there is a real risk, given the current policy, that Australia will become the poor cousin of the Asia-Pacific region. We will be the laughing-stock of a region which will profit at our expense because, having dumped basic research for short-term commercial research, we will be unable to make the scientific breakthroughs which take the world by storm and lead to the real commercial successes.

Only last month I visited Taiwan as part of a space delegation led by my colleague Senator Chapman. I have seen at first hand Taiwan's commitment to science and technology. It is very important that people note that Taiwan is on the same longitude as Australia and we have some very important common areas of interest. To say that I was impressed with what was happening in Taiwan would be a massive understatement. Taiwan's space program is much younger than ours—it only started in recent times—but we are being overhauled very rapidly by it.

For the representatives of the two major Australian space companies on the delegation, Dr Ian Tuohy of British Aerospace Australia and Mr Ted Stapinski of Auspace, the trip to Taiwan was a real eye-opener and I am confident that many doors will now be open to them. But no thanks to this government! It must be embarrassing for the minister and for the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht—who is responsible for the space program—that it was a coalition senator, Senator Chapman, who initiated this delegation to Taiwan over a long period of time. How embarrassing for the government that it was a coalition-led delegation that briefed the Taiwanese government on Australia's space program and provided the opportunity for Australian companies to investigate opportunities for collaboration.

How embarrassing that if British Aerospace Australia and Auspace are successful in forging links and cooperative ventures with Taiwan it will not be because of anything that the minister or Senator Schacht did. In fact, the minister even tried to put a spanner in the works by forbidding a senior CSIRO space scientist from going on the delegation with us, implying that it was not appropriate for him to accompany a coalition delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which minister was that?

—Minister Cook. It is the minister's prerogative to deny permission, but I am sure it did not earn him any brownie points with the Taiwanese government or CSIRO, which missed out on vital meetings with Taiwan's national space office and several government ministers. Of course, it is no secret that Senator Cook is not exactly CSIRO's biggest fan. He would not even answer questions at estimates last Thursday about how many times he had visited CSIRO research field stations in the last 12 months.

PARA.TAB: The minister was incredibly defensive about the whole issue. The Hansard of that hearing is not yet available, but, far from giving a commitment to providing the committee with this information, the minister said with extreme petulance that he would tell me if he wanted to and if he thought it was appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is arrogance.

—It is total arrogance. If it is not appropriate for me to ask questions at estimates about how many field stations the minister visited last year, I do not know what is appropriate. The only logical inference to draw is that the minister does not want to give the committee this information because he has visited so few research field stations and CSIRO sites since he became the minister that it is embarrassing.

PARA.TAB: This could also explain why the minister is so out of touch with what is happening inside CSIRO and why he would say that there was no need for a Senate inquiry. The minister says that there are no morale problems; no management problems; scientists are not under pressures to chase dollars instead of undertaking research; and CSIRO is not at risk of abandoning public interest research in pursuit of short-term research. The way the minister talks one would think everything was a bed of roses at CSIRO. I can assure the minister that it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going to sell it off.

—I have even heard a rumour that the minister regrets saying that there was no need for a Senate inquiry and that he privately agrees with a lot of the findings in the report which was, after all, a unanimous report from Liberal, Democrat and Labor senators. But, having criticised the inquiry so fiercely, he cannot now support it. Instead, he is stuck, like a shag on a rock, saying that all is well with the science research organisation.

PARA.TAB: Maybe the minister's realisation that he was wrong about CSIRO explains why he was so aggressive, ill-mannered and petulant at last Thursday's hearing. It is not often that I wish there were cameras at estimates hearings, but I wish we could have had them last Thursday night.

Finally, I want to comment on a statement that Senator Cook tabled at that estimates hearing. The minister states that it is wrong for non-government senators to talk about a $60 million cut to CSIRO's funding because, trotting out the old argument, he says that the $60 million was one-off funding which CSIRO always knew would come to an end. What a pity the minister did not mention the fact that, in the years prior to 1989, the Labor government ripped the guts out of science funding and it was only when the scientists protested long and hard that something was done about it.

The former minister for science, the member for Lalor, Mr Barry Jones, convinced the government to have a change of heart, and in 1989 the science statement effectively restored the $60 million to that funding. Senator Cook is conveniently ignoring what happened pre-1989, but the opposition will not buy that. The minister stated that 25 per cent of the top 10 per cent of tertiary students are enrolled in science courses. There is no doubt that we have very bright students enrolling for science degrees who go on to work in CSIRO. But the minister is ignoring other vital information. The fact is that only 25 per cent of students enrolling are from the top 25 per cent and 25 per cent are from the bottom, as Senator Coulter has said.

The minister has done nothing to address this problem. The government has taken no action to make careers in science more attractive to students and we, as a country, will have to suffer as a result. The consequences of Minister Cook's actions will be the decline of Australia's reputation in world class science and there is no point in blaming anybody else.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before us is the central issue of support for basic science. Basic science is that part of science that is done to find out how the world works without a clear application in mind. It asks questions such as: how gravity works; how matter is structured; what causes cell differentiation; what is the significance of yellow-green algae in the ecology? None of these questions have obvious commercial application; many have few obvious implications for any application. That does not mean that they have no application or that they are not important or even crucial.

PARA.TAB: Basic science laid the groundwork for all our existing technology. Most did not start out with obvious implications. Who would think that research into the ecology of sea urchins would be basic to saving the kelp industry, which in turn is basic to the processed food industry providing many substances like algin laminaran? Who would have expected the role that research into seaweed has in biotechnology and therefore in modern agriculture and pharmaceuticals? Who would have thought that research into the changes in electrical properties of clay due to impurities would result in the electronics revolution?

The thing about knowledge is that you cannot tell what it will be good for before you have done it. The implications for basic research only become clear once you have done it. If we have any pretence to being a clever country we must have basic research. The areas of commercially productive application are obvious to most scientists, especially if they are obvious enough to convince bureaucrats. Every nation has identified them and is working on them. The areas where real jumps will be made are the areas where applications are not obvious because no one is looking. The people who do the basic work are liable to be the first people to see the hidden implications.

CSIRO funding is mostly funding for application. Corporate research is all about application. The only sphere for basic research is universities. The push for greater self-funding and corporate funding of university research means that universities do more and more applied research and less and less basic research. It means simply that the success of research is increasingly measured by its immediate economic return. As this becomes a measure by which research is judged and funds become available, less and less basic research will be done. Universities become the research arms of industry, and commercial research players in their own right.

Free scientific information has always been the basis upon which science is done. Science is produced for all of humanity, available to everyone, especially colleagues who work in the field. Science is a communal activity and the sharing of ideas and information is central to the advance of our common understanding, undertaken ultimately for our common good. The reward of a scientist has always been recognition by her or his peers rather than monetary gain. The push for patenting undermines that and works against the common good. Governments create the environment that erodes or supports basic science. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition welcomes this motion by Senator Coulter. We support his view that this ALP government has failed to recognise the importance of science and the need for the government to fund the research effort properly.

PARA.TAB: There should be no need for this motion today. The Labor government has been warned continually about the perilous state of research and research infrastructure in this country. We have warned that Australia is spending only 1.35 per cent of its GDP on research and development and that this compares very poorly with other OECD countries and has compared poorly over the 12-year term of this government. Pro rata, we spend less than half the money that Japan, Sweden and Germany spend on R&D. They are leaders in this field and we are not.

Australia is failing to get the private sector to spend on collaborative research in the way that other countries are. Many multinational companies trading in Australia do their research overseas. If we want the research done here and the results to benefit the Australian people, the government must contribute a higher proportion to the collaborative research projects with private industry.

The coalition accepts that the federal government's role is to support research and research infrastructure. This needs to be a top priority because of the poor state that science in this country is in by world standards. Indications are that this poor standard is set to worsen. The relative science study citation published by Professor Bourke and others at the ANU shows that since 1987-88—which, people will recall, was the start of the so-called Dawkins revolution—the quality of science published by Australian researchers has fallen dramatically. According to the science citation index, the fall has been eight per cent. At a time when the index should be rising in a country like ours, it is actually falling.

The quality and the amount of research is going downhill fast. The Australian of 1 June quotes Professor Bourke and Linda Butler, this time on a new survey of international research links by Australian institutions, as saying that the evidence shows that the research effort in Australian universities is clumped in fewer than a third of the nation's 37 universities. Further, of that third, 85 per cent of the total research effort is undertaken by a handful of established older universities. At present the quality of science and research is dependent on people in their 50s and 60s who will be retiring in the next 10 or 15 years. This quality is not being replaced by young, able students; they are simply shying away from science research because the money and resulting research support infrastructure is not there.

This is a very sad record for a government that began 12 years ago with such hope in this area. It initially appointed a minister who knew something about the field. He had written a book on it, called Sleepers, Wake!, which was about the great need for improvement in spending on science in this country. At the time, many of us thought that with such a minister such a low priority on R&D would change. Indeed, that minister, Barry Jones, had a vision. His vision was 18 to 20 years ahead; unfortunately, he was in a cabinet which had a vision that was only 18 to 20 months ahead—the next election, which was all it was concerned about. It could not see how spending money for long-term benefit could improve the situation for the government at the next election.

Twelve years down the track the stark outcome of this lack of foresight and lack of spending is very evident. Currently, exports of scientific and medical equipment earn $782 million. That sounds pretty impressive until we discover that we are importing equipment to the value of $2.8 billion. That represents a deficit in spending in that area of over $2 billion. That is a result of the lack of foresight, lack of vision and lack of support from government for research and development.

Having had a poor record over the last 12 years, this government, with this current budget, shows a continuation of that pattern. What does it do in this budget for the premier research bodies? CSIRO drops 13 per cent in real terms. ANSTO drops five per cent. The Australian Institute of Marine Science drops three per cent. What forward planning and vision that is! A cost benefit study shows that research pays for itself over and over again but this short-sighted government does not see that. It sees it as more important to produce a bottom line budget that shows we are in surplus, even when that is done by the dodgy means of including the foreshadowed sale of the rest of the Commonwealth Bank. It is so concerned with getting a positive outcome in the budget that it has wrecked things that are important to our long-term future.

This has happened not only with the bodies I have mentioned but with our major universities, where funding for important research grants, such as ARC grants, is at a point where, when the success rate used to be 20 per cent, it is now 16 per cent. The facilities at our universities are deteriorating as the government fails to provide the spending on infrastructure that is needed. From this point on we must see that science is important to growth and expansion. We must fund government bodies and cooperative efforts with industry in an appropriate way. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to Senator Chamarette's return to order motion and table some documents. I seek leave to speak for three or four minutes on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has already taken up much of the Senate's time. Senator Chamarette has actively pursued the same subject matter for most of last week and previously in the estimates hearing of 26 May 1995. The senator clearly continues to believe that some secret deal has occurred between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), ATSIC and other parties. The fact that no deal did occur and the fact that the senator has no evidence of such a deal has not stopped her, with the support of those opposite, from wasting the time of this place and from continuing to make unfounded accusations.

PARA.TAB: Let me again make it very clear that the Prime Minister gave no undertaking or made any decision in respect of how much ATSIC should set aside for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. The ATSIC board made its own decision on how it would allocate its funds. In many ways this tabling motion is a farce. It is clear from her own admissions that Senator Chamarette has already obtained a copy of a number of documents which should have been treated with confidence. She would therefore be well aware that there was no secret deal or any secret agreement. Certainly, those papers did refer to discussions with the government and to negotiations. These discussions did not embrace financial allocations but referred to parallel programs and limitations of the ILC land purchases being claimable under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. There is nothing sinister or secret in those discussions.

Senator Chamarette and those opposite would have us believe that ATSIC's recent decision to set aside $10 million in each of the next two years for land acquisition in the Northern Territory was the child of this so-called secret deal. I am advised that considerable discussion took place at the board meeting with particular debate on whether funds should be set aside for the Northern Territory and, if so, the level of those funds. This level of discussion and debate within an independent board, which occurred, is inconsistent with Senator Chamarette's hypothesis.

Clearly, the ATSIC board was concerned that under section 191U of the legislation establishing the ILC, any land purchased through the ILC funding cannot be claimed under the Northern Territory land rights act. This means that Aboriginal groups wishing to acquire land and subsequently claim such land for conversion to inalienable freehold title under the Northern Territory legislation can only do so if the necessary funding support for the acquisition is not provided by the ILC. Therefore, until 1997, which is the sunset time for claims under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act, ATSIC will be positioned to continue to provide funding for acquisition in the Northern Territory.

Despite the illogical nature of the arguments put forward over the last week, the government acknowledges that Senator Chamarette has obtained numerical support for her motion. Therefore, the government has agreed to table a range of documents. Additionally, I put on the public record for those opposite that their support for Senator Chamarette's motion will result in the tabling of a number of documents which will breach confidences understood by various parties during negotiations on the ILC and the ILF.

I also put on the public record that those opposite clearly do not recognise or accept the principle that consultation processes leading to policy development are normally a matter of confidence between the various parties. Many of the documents contain material in the nature of giving or receiving of opinion, advice and recommendations, which are a fundamental part of the deliberative process of both ATSIC and the government. Additionally, the public disclosure of the views of individuals and groups put to ATSIC and government on a confidential basis may well impair the negotiating effectiveness of the commission and governments in the future.

The fact is that those opposite are willing to put all of that at risk and to establish a standard for which they themselves will be judged should they ever come to government. What is all the more disappointing is that they are prepared to put all that at risk because Senator Chamarette has a false suspicion.

As forecast yesterday, it is not proposed to table certain categories of documents. In particular, documents have been excluded which canvass matters before cabinet or which disclose any deliberation or decision of cabinet. In any event, none of the excluded documents reveal any discussions of a deal of the kind alleged by Senator Chamarette. Normally the government would not release legal advice provided to it by its solicitors on the ground of legal professional privilege. However, due to the gravity of the allegations made by the senator, the privilege in this instance is waived. The basis on which documents are being withheld is consistent with official guidelines and consistent with the government's general position in respect of such matters.

Having participated in this debate—coincidentally, I have been in the chamber over the last couple of days when debate has occurred on this matter—I apologise to the Senate for inadvertently misleading it and believing that we have done 15 minutes of government business in the last six days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Resign, Nick!

—It is terrible, isn't it? In fact, we have done three minutes of government business in the last six days. Before people rush to move more censure motions, I think I had better apologise to the Senate for that and express the wish and desire that we now finally get on with some government business, given that we have 55 pieces of legislation and about 12 days to go.

Preliminary Study—Overseas Visits by Defence Officers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not be spending a great deal of time taking note of this Auditor-General's report. I felt it is necessary because members of this Senate would know that I am usually the last person to stand up and congratulate the Department of Defence. I have been very concerned about levels of expenditure and accountability and policies and programs. However, I felt it is only fair that in areas where Defence is doing the right thing that I also do the right thing and acknowledge that it is.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the first part of this report—the project audit on energy management in Defence—the Auditor-General's office has made a fairly critical assessment of the way Defence has undertaken its obligations in relation to energy saving across departments. It is critical; it is not 100 per cent positive. But Defence has started that program. It is not something I can say about many other departments. The important thing also is that Defence has implemented or taken steps to implement the majority of the recommendations in the audit report. This seems to coincide with the information that I received on asking questions of Defence during the recent estimates hearings about its defence housing program. In relation to housing and regional development, I had already asked about the entire government's housing program and its efforts to implement energy standards within its program and was given very short shift in saying, `We don't know if we can do this. It might cost more money. We really don't want to be prescriptive on the environment.' For people who know, most of this can be regarded as nonsense.

I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 June 1995 entitled `Govt fails to switch on to energy savings'. This article says that the government is actually delaying saving money. Everyone should be able to understand that. The first paragraph states:

Millions of dollars of public money is being wasted every year because the Federal Government has largely failed to implement a promise made three years ago by the Prime Minister to cut energy use in its buildings.

SPEECH.PARA: Further on the article states:

In one example—the Bureau of Statistics' Cameron Offices, one of Canberra's biggest office complexes—a review in July 1993 found the building used 29 per cent more energy than was typical for a building of its size.

An energy audit was done and only now, more than two years later, is the recommended system being installed. So we are actually delaying saving money. There have been energy consultants involved in a number of energy audits but they remain frustrated because the targets identified in energy audits costing $1 million remain unachieved in many departments.

PARA.TAB: At a recent estimates committee hearing I asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) why performance is so poor in the area of integrating such things as energy goals or greenhouse goals into other departments. He said that it was not the role of Canberra to be involved with demand management. I reminded him that demand management was one of the responsibilities of his department. He changed the wording after that. He realised that perhaps he had said something pretty silly. In fact, we have this role. We could be doing it. Government could be leading the way instead of dragging its feet and costing the taxpayers money every time it delays implementing its own policies of demand management in its own facilities. So, well done, Defence for starting. If you can do it, so can everybody else. Let us see all the other departments getting on board. It is about time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Auditor-General's report No. 29 that has just been tabled in the Senate. Senator Margetts has very ably covered the first part of the report. I think praise is due to Defence, not only in the energy management field, but also in the environmental field where, for many, many years, long before environmental concerns became fashionable, Defence took a long-sighted view and recognised its responsibilities in maintaining training areas in land that it had around the country.

PARA.TAB: The point should be made that there are limited opportunities for energy savings within Defence. Certainly with respect to the purchase of new equipment and the design of buildings, those are matters that can be dealt with at the outset, but military platforms per se are designed for specific performance and fuel efficiency and energy efficiency are not the prime concerns. The other problem that the department has is that there is not much predictability from year to year.

I would like to move to the second audit, which is on the ANZAC ship program. That is a very brief and superficial look; the longest report is the first one. The report is entitled Preliminary study: ANZAC ship project contract amendments. Paragraph 1.2 on page 31 of report No. 29 contains an extraordinary statement:

Defence has estimated that the ten ships will now cost $5837 million in current (December 1994) prices, an increase of $1471 million over the base price established during April 1988. Of this amount, $1294 million is for price increases and exchange rate variations related to the prime contract with Transfield. The remaining $177 million relates to real increases associated with the larger gun, New Zealand spares, currency swap adjustments and a reallocation of travel funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the report deals with that minor amount of a few hundred million dollars, and ignores the increase of $1,471 million, which is a huge increase—33 per cent-plus—in the contract price. The government and Transfield go around boasting about how we have got a fixed price contract for the ships, yet here we have the first evidence presented in public, that I know of, of an increase in real terms—because the taxpayer has to pay for this—of 33 per cent in the cost of a ship.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the history of this Anzac frigate program, we see that there were two contenders in it: a very good Dutch design, and the Blohm & Voss Meko design which was accepted. The price differential, when the contract was accepted and we were told that the contract was awarded purely on price, was minuscule—I think it was about $5 million or $10 million per ship. That was the difference. I said at the time that would be eroded through the life of the contract, and so it has come to pass. We have got this increase of $1,471 million, about 33 1/3 per cent, giving us a figure of around $600 million for each of the ships.

Recently, the government announced that there was going to be a major increase in the number of weapons sensors and weapons on the Anzacs. SPEECH.PARA: DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill amends Defence legislation for the following purposes: to enable senior acting appointments to be made at ministerial level rather than by the Governor-General; to replace provisions under which officers hold their appointments at the Governor-General's pleasure; to implement recommendations of the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review; to extend the home loan assistance application deadline for a limited group of former members; and to ensure that the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme complies with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act. The bill also amends the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act to fill a gap in the entitlement to compensation for the unintended consequences of medical treatment provided at Commonwealth expense.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with these matters in turn.

The first amendment will enable the appointment of officers to act as the Chief of the Defence Force, Vice Chief of the Defence Force or as the chief of staff of an arm of the Defence Force to be made by a minister rather than the Governor-General. This will streamline the procedure and remove an unnecessary administrative burden from the Governor-General.

The second group of amendments concerns retirement and termination of appointments. At present, the Defence Act, Naval Defence Act and Air Force Regulations provide that officers hold their appointment at the Governor-General's pleasure. Under the existing provisions, officers could be retired or have their appointments terminated at any time and on any grounds or for no grounds at all. The Defence Force is the last major Commonwealth career group subject to the concept of holding office at pleasure. This concept is no longer appropriate to a career service.

The amendments to the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act replace the current blanket provisions with provisions that specify the grounds on which an officer can be retired early or have an appointment terminated. The amendments also introduce specific procedures for the management initiated early retirement of officers, and enable the promotion of senior officers on limited tenure where they accept a promotion on that condition. Corresponding amendments will be made to the Air Force Regulations.
While these amendments will give the Defence Organisation management flexibility, they also increase the level of protection available to affected officers.

Under the proposed provisions an officer could only be retired early or have an appointment terminated where one of the specified grounds is made out, or where the officer is subject to the management initiated early retirement procedures.

Where appropriate, an officer to be retired early or have an appointment terminated would be given the reasons in writing for the proposed action and an opportunity to show cause why it should not proceed. The main exception would be where the period of fixed term appointment had expired (often referred to as Short Service Commissions). Affected officers would also have the right to lodge an application for redress of grievance under the Defence Force Regulations and are entitled to submit a complaint to the Defence Force Ombudsman.

Similar safeguards apply to the management initiated early retirement procedures. In addition, I would emphasise that management initiated early retirement would only occur after all attempts to redeploy or retrain an affected officer had been exhausted and would be accompanied by the offer of a financial package.

The third group of amendments is to the Defence Force Discipline Act, which provides a scheme of discipline for all members of the Defence Force. When the legislation came into operation, provision was made for a Board of Review to review its operation after three years. The Board found that the scheme was generally adequate but made a number of recommendations to enhance its operation. The proposed amendments to the act would achieve this and also bring the act into line with Commonwealth Crimes Act provisions for the investigation of offences.

Perhaps the key amendments are those which enable the appointment of discipline officers to deal with minor infringements of discipline. The Board found that the present procedures for dealing with minor infractions are unnecessarily complex and administratively burdensome. A discipline officer will have the power to decide, with a minimum of formality, matters which do not have any element of criminality and to impose minor punishments. These will not carry the stigma of a criminal conviction.

I should emphasise that a discipline officer will only be able to deal with uncontested matters and a person who wishes to defend a matter will have the right to a full hearing under the ordinary provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act. Where an accused person does wish to have a case handled by a discipline officer, there will be no entitlement to representation but the right to call evidence in mitigation of punishment will apply.

Three new offences are created: unlawful discharge of a weapon; and refusal to submit to a medical examination, or supply a specimen, where a medical examination is being carried out as part of the investigation of a service offence. The latter offences will assist the prosecution of offences involving drug abuse. The Defence Force has in place a firm `no drugs' policy and the maximum penalty for use and possession of cannabis is to be increased from a fine equivalent to seven days pay to a fine of fourteen days pay for a first offence and dismissal from the Defence Force for a subsequent offence.

Sentencing options for minor offences will be enhanced by introducing the punishment of extra drill (to a maximum of 3 hours spread over 3 days), increasing the maximum period of extra duties (from 3 to 7 days) and enabling suspension of the payment of all fines.

Currently, members of the Defence Force who are suspended from duty pending the investigation of an alleged offence or suspended while awaiting trial for a civil or criminal offence are entitled to payment of salary and allowances. This entitlement will be removed where a suspended member has been charged with an offence. Such a member will, however, be entitled to engage in employment outside the Defence Force during the period of suspension. These changes will parallel the provisions applying to the Australian Public Service.

The remaining amendments to the Defence Force Discipline Act will streamline existing procedures for the conduct of investigations and hearings conducted by service tribunals, and bring certain provisions in the act, such as those dealing with confessions, into line with current Commonwealth Crimes Act provisions.
The fourth amendment is to the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act to overcome a defect in the administration of the Defence Force Home Loans Assistance Scheme.

In 1992, the act was amended to provide access to the Home Loans Assistance Scheme to persons who first enlisted in the Defence Force after 14 May 1985 and were discharged because of a compensable disability before 15 May 1991, provided these persons applied for an entitlement certificate by 1 September 1994.

While the changes to the act were publicised widely through Service and ex-Service channels at the time, it was nevertheless considered that the Commonwealth had a responsibility to attempt to contact every former member who might benefit and who might otherwise not become aware of the benefit. Unfortunately, some former members received late advice of the changes. As a result, some 17 applicants were debarred because the cut-off date of 1 September 1994 for lodging applications had already passed. Accordingly, the bill extends the time limit from 1 September to 1 December 1994 so that these persons will not be disadvantaged.
The fifth group of amendments is to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act. This act establishes the current superannuation scheme for members of the Defence Force.

The amendments will allow the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) legislation, which provides for enhanced prudential supervision of superannuation funds.

The amendments are of a technical nature and relate to the decision making powers and roles of the Board of Trustees and the Minister. They are similar to amendments made last year to the superannuation legislation relating to the Commonwealth civilian schemes.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) legislation requires, among other things, that trustees of superannuation entities not be subject to direction by any person and that the approval of the trustees must be obtained for any change to the governing rules of the scheme. In the case of the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme the governing rules would include the Trust Deed and Regulations.

The amendments remove the present requirement for the Trustees to have regard to statements of Government policy in exercising their functions, provide that financial statements be in a form agreed between the Board of Trustees and the Minister, and require the agreement of the Board of Trustees to any changes to the Trust Deed or Regulations.

The final amendment made by the bill is to the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act. In 1994 various amendments were made to that act in association with introduction of the Military Compensation Scheme. One amendment provided an entitlement for compensation for an injury that arises from medical treatment provided at Commonwealth expense where the injury is an unintended consequence of the treatment. Defence Force service (or specified Defence-related service) attracts the entitlement.

An unintentional effect of the amendment was that it did not cover the period between the enactment of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act in 1988 and introduction of the Military Compensation Scheme in 1994 (although the entitlement in question applied under the legislation that the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act replaced). The proposed amendment fills the gap so there is no period of service for which the entitlement does not apply.

Honourable senators will appreciate from my comments on the individual measures that this legislation is essentially part of the ongoing process of improving and modernising the administration of the Defence Force. With this in mind, I look forward to the Senate's support for the legislation. The estimated cost of the amendment to the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act is approximately $1 million although there will be considerable offsets in the avoidance of litigation. The other amendments are not expected to have a significant financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 1) 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill amends four acts dealing with superannuation for Commonwealth sector civilian employees, the Superannuation Act 1922, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1994. It also removes gender-specific terms from the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the bill is to make amendments to continue the process of ensuring that the two superannuation schemes for Commonwealth civilian employees comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and regulations under that act (SIS). I expect the Boards of Trustees of the two schemes to elect that the schemes become regulated superannuation funds under SIS with effect from 1 July 1995.

The bill will also make some technical amendments to the acts to name the schemes, the Boards of Trustees and the Funds as the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, the CSS and PSS Boards and the CSS and PSS Funds. This will ensure that the generally used names have a legal basis and will enable ease of reference in other legislation.

The opportunity has also been taken to include amendments to correct anomalies that have arisen and caused inequities. For example, to provide restoration of an invalidity pension that had been cancelled on a return to work that is terminated in the probationary period because of ill-health.

The bill includes amendments to restore the original intentions of the 1976 act as a response to the changing employment conditions in the public sector. For example the change to the definition of minimum retiring age in that act formally recognises that most members of the scheme are able to retire from age 55.

Also included are some amendments to assist administrative efficiency, for example, the Boards will be able to rely on advice from employers rather than have to check personnel records for over 200,000 members. These amendments will not prevent the Boards from correcting errors in such information nor interfere with members' appeal rights.
The bill includes several technical amendments and drafting corrections resulting from previous amendments and to remove gender-specific terms.

I now turn to the financial impact of the bill. The amendments to correct anomalies will increase the cost of the schemes slightly; most of the provisions designed to assist administration efficiency will decrease administrative costs or prevent increases in such costs; and a further administrative amendment will reduce the cost of the CSS but not the overall cost to the Commonwealth as there will be an offsetting compensation cost.
Because the anomalies occur only in unusual situations, it is likely that there would be no overall cost to the schemes or the Commonwealth from the proposed amendments.
Mr President, I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under mutual recognition, can meat produced for domestic consumption in those States where government meat inspectors have been removed from domestic abattoirs under industry self-regulation arrangements be transported and sold across State and territorial borders without further inspection or controls.

(2) What safeguards have been put in place to allow consumers to be informed of: (a) the State or Territory or origin of the meat they are purchasing to feed their families; (b) whether the meat they are purchasing has been inspected by companies under self-regulation arrangements; or by government-employed meat inspectors; and (c) whether the meat itself has been produced in an export registered or a domestic abattoir.

(3) In view of the difficulty of making the information referred to in (2) available to assist consumers to make informed decisions concerning the meat they purchase under existing fragmented meat inspection arrangements what interim measures are being taken to ensure national consumer protection until such time as the compulsory national meat inspection standards proposed by the Government are finalised and implemented.
(4) What steps are being taken to ensure a uniform, consistent level of compliance with the proposed new national mandatory meat inspection standards across the nation as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under mutual recognition, goods produced in one State which meet the legal requirements and standards for unconditional sale in that State or Territory may be sold in any State or Territory participating in the mutual recognition scheme without the need to comply with additional requirements in other States or Territories. This principle applies to meat as to other goods. Meat produced by self-regulatory systems is required to meet the same standards as meat produced under government inspection.
(2) No such arrangements exist.

(3) Existing meat inspection arrangements continue to maintain protection of consumers to a very high degree. Improved methods are continually under development or in the process of implementation. Commonwealth and State Governments have agreed that present codes of practice relating to the production of red meat should be reviewed and made mandatory for all slaughtering and meat processing establishments in all State and Territory jurisdictions. This process is proceeding. Any interim measures for implementation prior to introduction of compulsory standards as proposed would be a matter for State/Territory Governments to consider.

(4) Compliance by domestic meat processors with national standards is a matter for the relevant authorities of the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments. Commonwealth responsibilities relate to its role in providing domestic meat inspection in New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. A high level of compliance with established standards is achieved by the presence of AQIS inspection staff supported by regional administrative structures. AQIS's Compliance, Legal and Evaluation Branch is responsible for compliance investigations and consequential action, and program evaluation at appropriate intervals. For States other than New South Wales, compliance with nationally established standards is achieved through arrangements made by those States.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What role has the Australian Government played in the establishment of the new Australian International School in Hong Kong and what role will it play in the school's ongoing direction and management.
(2) Which Australian Government departments or agencies have been involved in the establishment of the school and what has been the nature of their involvement.
(3) What Commonwealth Government funding did the school receive initially and how much will it be receiving on an ongoing basis.
(4) Is it a fact that the Hong Kong Government has donated a plot of land for the school to erect a new $HK200 million building.
(5) Who is the current principal of the Australian International School.
(6)(a) Was the position of principal for the school advertised; if not, why was this considered unnecessary.
(7)(a) What is the current salary package of the principal of the school; and (b) how is this salary determined.

(8)(a) Was an official statement issued in response to allegations in the Hong Kong Sunday Post that Mr Davies had been dismissed from his two previous jobs and had accumulated a string of personal debts totalling more than $300,000; if so, what did the statement say.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian International School, registered with the Hong Kong Education Department, opened in February 1995. The school was set up in response to growing demand by Australians based in Hong Kong for schooling for their children in the face of insufficient places in the Hong Kong English school system. The Australian Consulate-General has been active in supporting efforts to create a community, non-profit school. It was involved in meetings with Australian community organisations in Hong Kong to consider proposals put forward to establish an Australian school.

The Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, in his capacity as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, wrote on 20 January 1995 to the Governor of Hong Kong, The Rt Hon Christopher Patten, asking him to consider allocation of a permanent site for the school. I also raised the matter when I subsequently met the Governor in London. This request is currently being considered.

Early liaison with the Hong Kong Government was carried out to establish the school as a community-based non-profit international school. As part of this evaluation, endorsement of the school by the Australian Consulate-General was sought, and was subsequently provided. The School Board judged it appropriate, in the light of this endorsement, for a representative of the Consulate-General to be appointed to the Board, at least for the initial stages of establishing the school.

As is evident from the foregoing, the Australian Consulate-General recognised the serious shortage of school places for Australian children in Hong Kong, and as a result played an appropriate role in the establishment of the new Australian International School. The need for the Consulate-General to continue this role beyond the initial stages of establishing the school will be kept under review.
(2) The Australian Government has been involved in the establishment of the school, in the manner described above.
(3) None.
(4) The Hong Kong Government has provided temporary accommodation for the school at a nominal rent until December 1996, and will consider allocation of land or permanent premises.
(5) The current principal is Mr Brian Davies.
(6)(a) No. The Board has indicated that it decided to appoint Mr Davies to head the school project on the basis of his qualifications and experience.
(7)(a)(b) The current salary package of the principal of the school has been based on that of other international school heads in Hong Kong. The level of Mr Davies' salary is a private matter.
(8) No official statement was issued by the Consulate-General in response to allegations in the Hong Kong Sunday Post. The School Board did however respond to the allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the fact that from 1 January 1995 refugees in Australia are able to qualify for a wide range of veterans' affairs payments and that these changes were announced in the 1994-95 Budget and apply to refugees who have been in Australia less than 10 years, is it possible for these payments to be made to person who fought against Australian troops in Vietnam and elsewhere?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The easing of residency requirements for refugees claiming service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs will not result in payments being made to a person who fought against Australian troops.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) specifically excludes from service pension eligibility an allied veteran who has served in enemy forces of Australia and her allies or in forces that were assisting the enemy of Australia and her allies.
